diagnoses: Viral infection (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex virus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Kawasaki disease is a condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It primarily affects children. Symptoms include fever, rash, red eyes, swollen lymph nodes in the neck, red, dry, cracked lips, a strawberry tongue, and swollen hands and feet. Early diagnosis and treatment of Kawasaki disease are important to prevent heart complications.}, {diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) / Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

justification: Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis are rare, serious disorders of the skin and mucous membranes. They are usually triggered by an infection or drug. The most common symptoms are fever, sore throat, headache, cough, and burning eyes. This is followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters. Early diagnosis and treatment of SJS/TEN are important to prevent life-threatening complications.}, {diagnosis: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

justification: Lupus is a chronic (long-term) disease that causes inflammation in different parts of the body. Common symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, fever, skin rashes, and kidney problems. There is no cure for lupus, but treatments can help manage the symptoms.}, {diagnosis: Infective endocarditis

justification: Endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves (endocardium). It typically occurs when bacteria or other germs from another part of your body, such as your mouth, spread through your bloodstream and attach to damaged areas in your heart. Symptoms include fever, chills, night sweats, fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, and swelling in the feet, legs, or abdomen. Early diagnosis and treatment of infective endocarditis are important to prevent serious complications.}, {diagnosis: Stills disease

justification: Adult-onset Still’s disease (AOSD) is a rare inflammatory disorder that causes fever, rash, and joint pain. The exact cause of AOSD is unknown, but it is thought to be triggered by an infection, autoimmune disorder, or malignancy. Early diagnosis and treatment of Stills disease are important to prevent long-term complications.}, {diagnosis: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a severe allergic reaction to a drug, most often a medication. The symptoms of DRESS typically appear 2–8 weeks after starting the medication and can include fever, rash, swelling of the face, lymph node enlargement, and internal organ involvement. Early diagnosis and treatment of DRESS are important to prevent life-threatening complications.}, {diagnosis: Reactive arthritis

justification: Reactive arthritis is a type of arthritis that occurs in response to an infection in another part of the body, most commonly in the intestines, genitals, or urinary tract. Symptoms include joint pain and swelling, eye inflammation, and urinary problems. Early diagnosis and treatment of reactive arthritis are important to prevent long-term joint damage.}, {diagnosis: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

justification: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a kidney disease that can develop after infection with certain strains of group A streptococcus, the bacteria that causes strep throat. Symptoms include swelling, decreased urine output, blood in the urine, and high blood pressure. Early diagnosis and treatment of PSGN are important to prevent kidney damage.}, {diagnosis: IgA nephropathy

justification: IgA nephropathy (Bergers disease) is a kidney disease that occurs when an antibody called immunoglobulin A (IgA) builds up in the kidneys, causing inflammation that damages the kidneys filtering units (glomeruli). Symptoms include blood in the urine, protein in the urine, and swelling in the hands, feet, or face. Early diagnosis and treatment of IgA nephropathy are important to prevent kidney failure.}, {diagnosis: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)

justification: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a disease that causes inflammation and bleeding in the small blood vessels of the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys. Symptoms include a rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and blood in the urine. Early diagnosis and treatment of HSP are important to prevent kidney damage.}

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Viral Hepatitis (e.g., Hepatitis A, B, C, E)
Migratory Edema (if persistent or recurrent, further investigation is needed)
Delayed Puberty (needs evaluation for underlying causes)
Allergies (consider if contributing to otitis media)
Thyroid Disorder (consider for edema and delayed puberty)
Autoimmune Disease (consider for unusual combination of symptoms)
Genetic Conditions (consider for rare or unusual combinations)
Hemorrhoids (while not directly related to the other symptoms, this should be addressed separately)
Mood disorders (e.g., bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder)
Viral hepatitis (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Inflammatory bowel disease (such as Crohns disease or ulcerative colitis)
Thrombocytosis (This symptom alone can be indicative of a variety of conditions, further investigation needed)
